tweet: The S&P 500 will be up 6 months in a row.  Turns out, these rare streaks are quite bullish.  In fact, a year after a 6 month win streak the S&P 500 was higher 18 of 21 times with a very solid 11.9% average return.

Domino's and Google IPO'd during summer 2004.  As big as Google is, people still like pizza. A lot. The performance of these two giants is something that surprises a lot of people.  After DPZ jumped 15% yesterday, the lead is only bigger.  (Not a recommendation of either stock)
The bottom line is market breadth has been deteriorating behind the scenes.  This isn't end of the world stuff, but after a 90% rally for the S&P 500, it has been suggesting a break could be needed.
Google Trends says that searches for the word 'inflation' has never been higher.  Again, higher inflation is coming, but it sure won't be much of a surprise.

Remember when Exxon was kicked out of the Dow (after 92 years) and it was a 'sign of the times'?  Wouldn't it be quite the sign that the removal actually marked a major change in energy performance and was a major buy signal?  Here's energy versus the SPX.

9 of the past 10 years when the S&P 500 was up >5% in April, the month of May was also higher (since WWII).  This year could make it 10 of 11.   Also, May historically starts strong and ends strong, the middle is trouble.  Amazing how history seems to rhyme.
The S&P 500 is higher 52% of the time on any given day. This goes up the longer you are willing to hold.   In fact, if you can hold for 25 years, the S&P 500 has never been lower.
Death, taxes, and stocks up in April?  Ben Franklin might need to add to his famous quote.  The S&P 500 added 5.2% last month and has now been higher in April 15 of the past 16 years.

The S&P 500 will be up more than 15% the previous 6 months heading into Sell in May during the first year of the Presidential cycle.  Since WWII only happened twice, in '45 and '61.  The next 6 months gained 12.2% and 5.1% back then.

When the S&P 500 doesn't close beneath the December low during Q1 the returns the full year are extremely strong.  Up 18.4% on average and higher 33 out of 35 times.  It just happened again in '21, which could have bulls smiling.
The second quarter during a post-election year is usually pretty good for the S&P 500.  Will 2021 follow suit?

The S&P 500 has 15 new all-time highs already in '21.  But what really matters is knowing that new highs happen in clusters that can last a decade or more.   We've been sharing this chart for a few years now and continue to expect history to rhyme.

Incredibly, the S&P 500 has finished green in April 14 of the past 15 years.  Other than a B1G basketball team choking in March, I can't think of anything more consistent.  (I'm an Ohio boy, I can say it)

Is 8% GDP growth in '21 good for the S&P 500? Using a regression line it comes out to a 6.9% return.  This might surprise some people, but stocks actually do better when GDP is negative.   How? Similar to what we saw last year, stocks sniff out the recovery before it happens.

So what are we celebrating today?  3/09/09 the S&P 500 closed at 676, ending the 54% bear market sparked by the Great Financial Crisis.  3/09/20 the 10-year yield closed just under 50 basis points, which just might have ended the 40 year bull market in bonds.

Here are all the S&P 500 corrections since 1980.  The returns a year or two later are truly spectacular.   It isn't easy in the moment, but for longer-term investors, when stocks go on sale is when you should go shopping.

The headlines might talk about market volatility, but that simply isn't happening.  Today was the 7th day in a row the S&P 500 didn't close up or down at least 0.5%.  That's ties the longest streak since 7 in a row during the dog days of August.

The headlines might talk about market volatility, but that simply isn't happening.  Today was the 6th day in a row the S&P 500 didn't close up or down at least 0.5%.  That's the longest streak since 7 in a row during the dog days of August.

The past 3 times the S&P 500 closed lower were by 0.06%, 0.03%, and 0.11%.   Dec 2019 was the last time 3 days saw similar small losses 3 times in row.   We hear a lot about all the volatility, I'd argue it is the opposite. Things are actually historically calm lately.

The S&P 500 up the first 6 days of February is the longest win streak to start any month since 6 in August 2020 and 6 in April 2019.  No month has started with a 7 day win streak since September 2013. Could happen tomorrow...
The S&P 500 is officially up the first 6 days of February.  Tying the longest streak to start any February ever (1962 also had 6).  Green tomorrow would break another record.

So goes January goes the year?  Final 11 months of the year up 11.9% on average for the S&P 500 if higher in January versus up only 1.7% if lower.  The January Barometer says a negative January (like 2021) could be a warning for the rest of the year.
The S&P 500 is up 14.0% from the election until the inauguration.  If it can close here, this would be the best rally ever over this timeframe, topping the 13.3% gain under Hoover.
Kind of amazing, but the Dow has never made a new high the same day a President was inaugurated.  This goes all the way back to McKinley in 1897.  With a good day tomorrow,  could be the first.

A good start to the year can be a sign of better times ahead.  The first 5 days of 2021 saw the S&P 500 up a very impressive 1.8% YTD.  Historically, when the first 5 days are up >1.5% the full year has been up 15.6% on average and higher more than 90% of the time.

The S&P 500 needs to gain 3.88% today to get to a 20% gain in 2020.  Don't get too excited, as since WWII, the final day gained more than 2% only once in 1974 (2.08%).  Still, from down 31% YTD in March, I'll take it.

Is a strong year-end rally a sign? Looks like it.  Since WWII, S&P 500 >10% in November and December only 5 times.  2020 will be number 6.  The following year was higher every single time, up 18% on average.  1955  26.4% 1963  18.9% 1971  10.8% 1986  14.6% 1999  19.5% 2021   ???%

30 new highs for the S&P 500 Index so far this year.  We've noted many times the past few years that new highs happen in clusters that can last a decade or more.  This cluster is 7 years old. Be aware history says it can last much longer than you probably think.
Big gains in November can steal from Santa in December.  What'll it be?  Avg December gains 1.5% for the S&P 500.  But down 1.0% when November gains >10%.  But up 2.0% when YTD up 10% or more.

The Russell 2000 (small caps) is officially up 20% for the month of November, which would be the best month ever.  For comparison, the S&P 500 gained 20% or more during a month 5 times, but all took place in the super volatile '30s.

25th new high for the S&P 500 this year.  But what we've been saying for years is new highs happen in clusters that can last a decade or more.  Many don't believe this is possible, but history would say be open to it.
Here are all the major Dow 1k milestones in history.  If it can close above 30k today, this one took 218 trading days to happen, which is an annualized return of 3.9%.

On a total return basis, the S&P 500 is up 13.2% this year.  Turns out, after it is up more than 30% (like '19), the returns the following year are quite strong, up 15.2% on average.  In other words, 2020 is pretty much doing what you'd expect.
The S&P 500 is up 2.7% today and set to make a new high.  This could be the best new high since Aug '91 and November '82 before that.
Today could be the first new high for the Dow since 2/12/20.  It would also be the 117th new high under President Trump.  Here's where than ranks with other presidents.

Since 1900, the Dow has made 1,334 new all-time highs.  Today could be number 1,335.  As of right now, the Dow is up +4.44%.   This would be the largest gain during an all-time high ever. Whoa.  AnotherAmazing2020Record

The S&P 500 added more than 7% last week, for only the 4th time the past 10 years.  One month later it was higher all 4 times and up another 7.7% on average.   This morning's gains could help continue this strength.

Since WWII, only 3 other times has the S&P 500 gained 1% or more for 4 consecutive days.  Yes, this is a small sample size, but I think it also shows how rare and potentially powerful this new signal could be.  Extremely strong 6- and 12-month returns historically.
During an election year, November is the best month of the year for the S&P 500.  December is the third best month.  Will 2020 follow suit and end up strong?

The S&P 500 is up 7.3% since 8/3/20 (3 months before the election).  Historically, a strong stock market has been a good sign that the incumbent party would win.  In fact, no President has ever lost an election with stocks up >7% the 3 months before the election.
During an election year the S&P 500 peaks today (Sept 21) and bottoms the last week of October.  The calendar very well could be the biggest issue if you are bullish right now.

Just because the S&P 500 has finished in the red the past two times it traded on September 16 doesn't mean we still shouldn't wish  a happy birthday!  Happy 5-5, Howard! You've helped so many people over the years and you've greatly helped me, thank you!

The S&P 500 was up 7% last month.  Here's what it did the next month the past 15 times it was up at least 7%.   You might notice a pattern.  5.0%  5.9%  (3.1%) 0.5%  0.8%  5.7%  5.1%  9.4%  5.3%  3.4%  3.7%  (0.5%) 0.1%  3.0%  4.5%   Avg 3.2%

At the lows this year, the Dow was down 34.9% YTD.  Since 1900, the most it has ever been down and finish the year green was -25.4% in 2009.  This could be yet another record for 2020 when all is said and done.

The S&P 500 will likely be up in August (up 7% with a day to go).  This means it will be green in April, May, June, July, and August.  What has happened next?   Other than the Fed policy mistake of December '18, significant strength is the answer.
Last time July and August saw the S&P 500 gain more than 5% in each of those months? (Has a shot at happening in 2020 btw)  1932.  Yes, big summer rallies like this are what we'd call rare.

If it feels like stocks have been up just about every day in August, that's because they pretty much have.  The S&P 500 has closed green 14 days so far this month.   With 3 more tries, if it can get to 15 green days in August, that'd be the most for any August since 16 in '03.

The last time the S&P 500 gained in April, May, June, July, and August (like they will in '20)?  2018. Down 13.6% the rest of the year.  But before that (since '50) the previous 5 times were all higher and up 10.9%.

5 yrs ago tomorrow was 1st time Dow was down 1,000 points.  I'll never forget it. I was unemployed and at a back Doctor's office. Could barely walk, in constant pain, and market was collapsing.  Today my back is great and I'm a Chief Market Strategist.  Keep grinding guys.

So the S&P 500 is up 4 straight weeks.  Going back to 2015, here are the returns the next 4 weeks after a 4 week win streak. You might notice a pattern.  0.7% 1.3% 0.4% 1.2% 1.5% 4.1% -4.4% 0.8% 2.0% 3.9% 0.3% 2.4% 3.4%
Amazing what a 50% rally in the S&P 500 will do for sentiment.
This seems fitting, 2020 will remain stuck on 13 new highs for the S&P 500 Index.  Maybe tomorrow it can get off of unlucky 13.

With the S&P 500 about to make new all-time highs, the number one question we get is how can this happen when the economy is still overall quite weak?  Well, the S&P 500 isn't GDP and here we list four great ways to explain this.

Here are all 32 corrections in the S&P 500 since 1980.  The one constant is returns 1- and 2-yrs out are very strong.   They say that the stock market is the only place where prices go on sale and people run out of the store screaming.   This chart will hopefully help next time.
More new highs for the NYSE A/D line today.  Historically, this peaks about about a year before the S&P 500, so new highs should suggest this bull market isn't done quite yet.
Unfortunately, Bezos just bumped me! I might not open my latest Amazon package for two days to get even.

The last time (before 2020) both gold and the S&P 500 made new highs in the same year was 1979.  This isn't as bearish as you might think, as gold added another 17% and the SPX 26% in 1980.  "An object in motion stays in motion" comes to mind here.
The first cover was the same week as the S&P 500 bottom in March.  The other one is last week.  Amazing what a 46% rally in the S&P 500 will do to sentiment.
At the 3/23 lows, the S&P 500 was down 30.7% YTD.  It is currently up 1.6% YTD.  No year has ever finished green that was down at least 30% YTD at one point.   2020 could...

One worry for 2020?  The first half of the year saw the S&P 500 down 4%.  Historically, how the first 6 months do can predict the final 6 months.  If higher? Rest of yr up 77% of time and up 5.8% on avg.  If lower? Up 52% of time and 1.2% on avg.

Another reason stocks very well could climb back and finish green for the yr?  The S&P 500 hasn't finished a yr lower (total return) the last 10 yrs there was a split Congress.   '85, '13, and '19 are some of the best yrs ever for stocks and all took place with a split Congress.

The four most dangerous words, "This time is different."  Well, what isn't different is the S&P 500 has never been lower the quarter after gaining 15% or more.   A summer lull makes sense, but it could be a buying opportunity.

S&P 500 down 20% in Q1, for the worst Q1 EVER.  Only to follow it up with a 21.1% gain in Q2 so far, which would be the best Q2 since '38.  What did the final 6 months do in '38? Up 5.9% in Q3 and another 7.4% in Q4.

Remember, it takes an average of 20 months for the S&P 500 to recover from a bear market. Longer if in a recession.  The S&P 500 is only 6% away from new highs, which if it happens over the coming months would make this one of the fastest bear market recoveries ever.

The S&P 500 on a total return basis is up in 2020.  Love this quote from Jesse Livermore, as I'd say 2020 hasn't been obvious to nearly anyone.  “The stock market is never obvious. It is designed to fool most of the people, most of the time.” Jesse Livermore

S&P 500 EPS cut 28% ($178 to $128) first 5 mos of 2020 via    Topped the record 26.4% drop the first 5 mos of '09.   Remember what Art Cashin told us many years ago.  "Never bet on the end of the world. It never ends, and if it does, who will you settle the trade with?"
Remember, the last time the S&P 500 was down 30% year-to-date and finished green was never.  Down 5.4% YTD right now, will it finally happen in 2020?
The S&P 500 is now up 36.6% from the March 23 lows.  Not saying it can't happen, but this would be extremely rare to 'just be a bear market rally'.
The S&P 500 has gained 35.7% from the March lows.  This would make it the greatest bear market bounce ever.   Which opens the question, is this not just a bear market bounce?
The S&P 500 is up >4% in May with a few days to go.  This could be 7 of the past 8 years and 13 of the past 18 it closed higher.
The S&P 500 fell 20.0% in Q1, for the worst Q1 in history.  The S&P 500 is currently up 17.4% in Q2, which would be the best Q2 quarter in 82 years.

As the SPX is down 6% YTD, can it really finish positive after being down 30% YTD at the lows?  2 things to consider:  1.) SPX higher the year after it gains >28% (like 2019) 6 out of last 6 times 2.) SPX higher 10 out of past 10 times a President was up for re-election

Here's a tweet about the Dec '18 lows holding and a bullish engulfing pattern on the SPX suggesting a bounce.   Check out the replies. Sentiment was so lopsided then and is partly why this has been one of the best 40-day rallies ever.

At the lows, the S&P 500 was down more than 30% YTD. It is down 8% YTD right now.  There has never been a year that was down that much come all the way back to green.  Here are the previous largest reversals.  Can 2020 do it?

Only Oct '74 and Jan '87 saw better monthly returns for the S&P 500 than April '20.  Six months later it gained another 18.1% and 16.3% those two times, respectively.  Here are all the returns after a 10% monthly gain. Bulls will like this.
Over the past 20 years, the S&P 500 has bottomed around tax day (April 15th) and rallied the rest of the month.  With no April tax day this year, will it happen again?
The S&P 500 was down 30% YTD a few weeks ago, now there is talk it could go green when 2020 is all done.  We take a look at this potentially record breaking reversal...

Although this question seemed ridiculous 3 wks ago, could the S&P 500 actually close higher in 2020?  At a YTD loss of >30%, it would be the first year to ever be down that much and close green.  The current largest reversal is 2009 at down 25.1%, yet closed higher for the yr.

Since January 24, the S&P 500 has been gained on Friday only twice.  That is two green closes out of 11.  No one appears to want to hold over the weekend.  Today is like a Friday, so will investors hold over a 3-day weekend?

At the lows, the S&P 500 was down 30.75% YTD in 2020.  The most any year has ever been down and still finished green?  2009 was down 25%, but finished green.  Can it happen this year? Good news is there is still plenty of time. Bad news is there is still plenty of time.

The S&P 500 is down 20.0% YTD.  This is the worst Q1 ever.  The good news? (we could use some)  Previous worst Q1 in '38 down 19.4%, yet the rest of the year gained an incredible 54.6% to finish the year up 24.5%.
The S&P 500's 200-week EMA was support at the Feb '16 and Dec '18 lows.  This won't go down without a fight and is a likely place for a near-term pullback.
The S&P 500 hasn't been up back-to-back days for 28 days.  This ties the longest streak since WWII.  It was green yesterday, will it be green again today?
If you connect the 1929 high for the Dow with the 1999 high and extend...  The good news is now Mr. Market can reset before another assault higher.

S&P 500 has alternated between green days and red days for 7 consecutive days now.  Red on Friday, so this back and forth could end today.  All-time record was 14 alternating days set in March/April 2013.
25 days in a row the S&P 500 hasn't been up back-to-back days.  28 is the most ever.  This has happened only 10 times since WWII.  Up today, will it be green again tomorrow?
Worked on this tonight and it is pretty interesting.  How quickly could the S&P 500 recover the 30% loss?   Here are all the bear markets since 1950 and how long they all took to recover the losses.

Here are the 31 other times the S&P 500 pulled back at least 10%.  Yes, we don't know when this current weakness will bottom, but historically stocks are higher 90% of the time a year later after the eventual bottom.
Make that 6 consecutive days the S&P 500 changed at least 4% (up or down), tying the all-time record from November 1929.  Given futures are limit up right now, tomorrow could be a new record.
Pretty clear no one wants to hold over the weekend, as the Dow has been down the past 7 Fridays.  Most since 8 in a row in 2006.  FridayThe13th could get interesting.

The S&P 500 Index could fall into bear market territory today (20% off highs).  This would be the quickest move from a new all-time high to a bear market ever. 16 days.  Nearly twice as fast as the previous record in 1929.
Another sign of potential capitulation is the % of stocks in the S&P 500 beneath their 200-day MA is getting quite washed out.  Of course, this number could go much lower today.

Although no one knows when this correction will end, take note looking at the 31 other corrections since 1980 shows the S&P 500 is higher a year later 90% of the time.  Futures and quite scary right now, but this helps provide some important context.

If the S&P 500 closes up or down at least 2.5% tomorrow, it will have done that rare feat every day of the week (Monday to Friday weeks only).  The other times that happened?  December '08, October '33, and November '29.

They say that 'diversification means always having to say you’re sorry.'  Unless of course you consider last wk was the best wk for 20-year Treasuries since '13 and the best week for the Agg in 5 years.  S&P 500 down 11% will leave a mark few will ever forget, but bonds helped.
The S&P 500 could be down 5 straight days after making a new high (if red today).  That last happened in July '19 and Dec '14 before that.
The S&P 500 could be looking at 4 consecutive all-time highs today (if closes green).  Hasn't done that in February since 2017 and 1996 before that.

10 new all-time highs for S&P 500 in 2020.  More important though is understanding that new highs happen in clusters that can last decades.  This always makes the perma-bear crowd mad (at least it has for the past 6 years I've been sharing it), but isn't something I'd ignore.
The S&P 500 hasn't had back to back losses for 30 trading days in a row, tying the longest streak since 1955.  Given it was lower on Friday, a red day today would end this streak.
This is amazing.  The S&P 500 hasn't closed down consecutive days for 30 trading days in a row.  If it is higher on Monday, this will be the longest streak since 1955. Wow.

The S&P 500 is up 2% in January.  If it can close green this would be 5 consecutive higher months.  Take note, since 1950, the S&P 500 has been higher a year after a 5 month win streak an incredible 25 of 26 times.  Momentum can be a wonderful thing.

Here's what the avg year, election year, up for reelection, and year after a 28% gain look like for the S&P 500.  Note, things are better when a president is up for reelection and following a 28% gain.  Both could set up this bull to continue in 2020.
If the S&P 500 is up 0.04% each day of the year, it will finish up 10% for the year.   Which means at today's 0.84% pace it'll gain 212%.

The largest correction for the S&P 500 in 2019 was only 6.8%.  This is about half of the average year, which sees a max correction of about 14%.  If all you followed was the headlines, you'd never believe last year was quite calm.

Today will be the 6th new all-time high for the S&P 500 in December.  Somewhat surprisingly, 7 (most recently in 1999 and 2013) is the most this most bullish month of the year has seen since 10 back in December 1954.

You might hear how stocks are up a lot and this means next year will be bad.  Not necessarily.  S&P 500 could be up >30% (total return) in 2019. Historically, the following year has been higher 10 of 12 times and the avg. return is 15.2%.
Should we fear FridayThe13th?  Well, the S&P 500 has been down in December on this day three consecutive times ...

Does this look like a blow off top?  The S&P 500 is only 7.6% above the peak from 2018.  This isn't even above the average year of 8.5%.  If my  can win a game, anything is possible. Still, this doesn't feel like a blow off top.

Since WWII, the S&P 500 has gained >20% (total return) 26 times.  It fell into a recession the following year twice. In 1981 and 1990.  In other words, a recession is always possible, but history would say stocks up nicely tends to suggest an economic expansion the following yr.
If red the first two days of December has you down, you would have hated 1980 when the S&P 500 was down the first 9 days of the jolliest month of them all.
Today will likely be the 33rd day in a row the S&P 500 doesn't trade in more than a 1% intraday range (from lows to highs).  If things seem boring, it is because they are.
12.) When the S&P 500 doesn't break the December low during Q1, the full year has been higher 34 out of 34 times.   Up 22.1% on average.  This year could be 35.
Today will be the 29th consecutive day without the S&P 500 being down back-to-back days.  That is the longest streak since March 2005.

If you invested $1 in the Dow on the first day it traded, you'd have $684 today.  Yes, this doesn't factor in inflation, divs, or real life, but still a powerful reminder that over time investing in equities tends to be the way to go.

Pretty amazing the lack of volatility lately.  Over the past 7 days the Dow has moved (from the previous day's close) less than a point, 6 points, 10 points, another point, and exactly flat for the first time in years.  This simply won't stay this way, get ready for a big swing.

What happens the year after the S&P 500 is up >20% for the year?  Up 9 of the past 10 years with an average return of 14.3%.  Anything can happen, but big drops the year after a big gain are quite rare.

Not to mention sense the November 1982 new highs (and that bull market starting), we've seen the S&P 500 up a median of +13.5% a year after new all-time highs vs median return of +11.3%.  Suggesting new highs might feel scary, but returns are actually stronger.
The S&P 500 has made 16 new all-time highs so far in 2019.  Remember, new highs tend to happen in clusters that can last more than a decade.
Will there be a chase into year-end?  Well, the previous 7 times the S&P 500 was up >20% at the end of October saw November up 7 times and December up 6 times.

The last time the Fed cut rates when the S&P 500 closed at a new all-time high the day before the cut? (Note it could happen today)  1/31/1996  This was also the third cut in a row of 25 basis points after a cycle of tightening.  +21.5% S&P 500 a year later.
2019 could be the first year the Fed cuts rates 3 separate times with the S&P 500 within 1% of an all-time high.  1983 and 1986 had two cuts within 1% of new highs.
October 28th might have the best avg return per day for the S&P 500, but did you know that November 14 has the most new highs ever at 11?

If today seems like a slow day, that's because it has been.  With 20 minutes to go, S&P 500 has traded in a range of only 0.33%. This would be the second smallest day all year (7/15/19 is the smallest).  columbusday2019

Going back to the Great Depression, the S&P 500 in October has the three largest 1-day drops ever and 6 of the worst 10 days ever.  It also has 3 of the top 10 1-day gains ever.  Pick a reason why, but October can have some big swings.

If you had the S&P 500 this week would see daily changes of 31, 26, 3, and 0 basis points after the attacks on the Saudi oil fields I don't think anyone would have believed you back on Sunday night.  But that's exactly what has happened so far.

So much for September being volatile.  The S&P 500 has closed within 0.1% of the previous day's close 6 of the past 10 days.  Over the past 2 wks we've had the Fed, Iran attacks, ECB, crude spike, repo market, QB injuries .... who would have ever expected markets to be so calm?

The S&P 500 gains +22.1% on avg when it doesn't close beneath the December lows during Q1. Also up for the year 34 out of 34 times.   Up only +3.1% when it closes beneath the Dec low.  Given 2019 didn't close beneath the 12/24/18 lows in Q1, will this year be 35 for 35?
The S&P 600 could be up >1% three consecutive days for the first time since January.  Incredibly hit 7 days in a row in October 1998.
Since 1960, the S&P 500 has averaged a 7.4% annualized return.  The current 4.1% return puts in perspective how little stocks have really gained the past 2 decades (but two 50% crashes will do that).
If the S&P 500 closes above 2,901 today - this would mark 25 out of 26 times it was higher a year after a 5 month win streak.   Didn't think this would play out in December, but here we are...

The % of stocks in the S&P 500 above their 200-day MA is just above 50%.  This area has marked lows in the past.   The big clue if more pain could be coming is if this is violated, similar to what we saw last October.
Of course, we don't know if the nearly 3% drop yesterday will be the worst day of 2019, but be aware the average worst day of the year for the S&P 500 is down more than 4%.  Bad days happen.

Only 7 times since WWII has the S&P 500 been up more than 20% at the end of July. (Could happen this year).  August has been down 5 of those years and the last time it happened (1997), the S&P 500 was down 5.7% in August.  Hmm.

Looking like we'll see a rate cut with the S&P 500 within 2% of an all-time high (using closing price for SPX the day before the rate cut date).  Remember, this has happened 17 times since 1980.  S&P 500 was higher a year later every single time.

Who will win the next US Presidential election?  Stocks might tell us, as they've accurately predicted every winner since 1984. Along with being right 20 of the past 23 elections.  S&P 500 performance 3-months before the election has a solid track record.
SPX wasn't within 2% of new highs then.  Only did a scan for rate cuts near highs. Cuts with stocks off highs can absolutely happen during more troublesome times.
Can the Fed really cut rates with stocks at new highs?  Going back to 1980, they've done it 17 times (SPX within 2% of new highs).  A year later? The S&P 500 was higher all 17 times.

Could the Fed really cut rates with stocks up big?  Well, since 1975, there have been 26 times they cut rates with the S&P 500 YTD return >15%.  A year later? Stocks were up 13.4% on avg and higher 23 out of 26 times.
After 14 trading sessions, the S&P 500 is up 7.3% in June.  This is the best start to a month since October 2011 and would be the best overall June since 1955.
AAII bulls <30% for 6 consecutive weeks, longest since November 2016.  AAII bears>bulls for 6 consecutive weeks, longest since February 2016.  The S&P 500 could make a new all-time high today.

Right on cue, the S&P 500 bottomed as the % of stocks >200-day MA in the SPX hit 50%.   As you can see, this has been support multiple times the past few years.  The only time it broke was in Q4 '18 and that was a major warning something was wrong.

Will the Fed really cut rates next week with the S&P 500 only 2% away from new highs?  Although we don't expect a cut next week, did you know the Fed has cut rates on the same day as new highs in the past?    Happened recently in:  Jan '06, July '95, Aug '91, July '89 and '90,

If red today, the S&P 500 would be down every day of the week (Monday - Friday).  This would be the 2nd time that has happened in 2019 (happened in March).  You have to go back to 1996 the last time that happened twice in the same year. Likely doesn't mean much, but interesting.
The S&P 500 has pulled back only 2.5% all year, one of the least volatile starts to a year ever.  Here we discuss why some volatility would be perfectly normal ....

Since 1990, April OpEx (option expiration week) is the most bullish week of the year - up +1.04% on average.  This week is April OpEx. With the S&P 500 less than 1% from new all-time highs, can it get there?
S&P 500 EPS estimates the next 12 months have stabilized after the recent uncertainty.   Q1 EPS might not be great (we expect flat YoY), but bodes well for a pick up in EPS the second half of '19.
The S&P 500 is up 23.2% from the 2018 lows.  Remember though, it is up 32.0% on average a year after midterm year lows.  It won't be a straight line, but does say the bull can continue in 2019.
The S&P 500 hasn't been up 9 days in a row for 15 years.  Could happen today.

The 2/10 yield curve spread will someday invert.  Just remember that the previous three times that happened the S&P 500 didn't peak for more than 20 months later and was up an average of more than 30%.  Also, all three times significantly outperformed the avg yearly return.

In 2016, the NYSE advance/decline line made a new high in April and the S&P 500 followed suit and made new highs three months later in July.  This year the NYSE AD line made new highs last month. Will 2019 follow the pattern of 2016 and see the S&P 500 make new highs soon?

More new highs on these A/D lines today:  Dow NDX NYSE OEX SPX  Yes, this doesn't mean we can't have a pullback - remember 2016 had the Brexit selloff AFTER the NYSE A/D made new highs, but this is usually a sign any weakness could be a buying opportunity.
One of my favorite market stats is how we tend to see a lot of green around StPatricksDay .  You can't make this up, the S&P 500 historically is quite green this time of year!

S&P 500 up 11.1% YTD, for the best start to a year since 1991.  Now where things get interesting is here comes the historically strong March and April months.   Pullback or can the bull keep it going?

The past 27 times the S&P 500 was higher in both January and February saw the final 10 months gain 25 times. Additionally, the avg return is 12.1% versus an avg final 10 mos of 7.6%  This year could be number 28...
How persistent has the strength been since late December?  Today could be the 35th consecutive day the S&P 500 closes above its 10-day MA.  That would be the longest streak in nearly NINE years.
Looking like the S&P 500 will be higher in both January and February.  Since '50? Happened 27 times and the final 10 months were higher 25 times and up >+12% on avg.

TGIF?  If higher today, the S&P 500 will be up 7 of the 8 Fridays this year (87.5%).  Remember during weak markets you tend to see selling ahead of the weekend.  Since '70, when at least 62% of Fridays are higher = the full year has been higher 7 for 7 and up +24.7% on avg. Hmm.

The Fed's balance sheet peaked at $4.52 trillion on 1/14/15 and is down 11.8% from the peak currently.  The S&P has added 39% since the balance sheet peaked.  Remember when we were told a shrinking balance sheet would lead to a crash?

Since '50, the S&P 500 has been up in both January and February 27 times. This year could be number 28.  Think about this now:  25 of those times the final 10 mos were higher ('87 and '11 didn't work).  Avg return is +12.1% those final 10 mos vs avg final 10 month gain of +7.6%.
You'd think ValentineDay would be red, but turns out the S&P 500 has been lower on this day only twice going back 16 years.

Remember, the S&P 500 is up an avg of +32.0% a year after the midterm year lows. Also, been higher every single year since WWII.  Since the 12/24/18 lows? The S&P 500 is up +16.7%.   It won't be an easy ride, but this suggests room for the bull to run.
The S&P 500 advance/decline (A/D) line will likely make a new all-time high today.  It could be just me, but that usually isn't bearish.
The S&P 500 lost 3.75% on the day Fed Chairman Powell was appointed the job (Feb 8, 2018).  It has closed red at each FOMC meeting since then.  Will history repeat today?

The S&P 500 hasn't had a 4-day win streak in nearly four months (78 trading days).  That is the longest streak without a 4-day win streak since the US election in Nov '16 (83 days).  If green today, it would be up 4 in a row.

Since WWII, the S&P 500 has been down two years in a row only three times.  Once during the '73/'74 recession and then twice during the tech bubble in the early 2000s.  In other words, without a recession in 2019, history would say another down year in 2019 would be quiet rare.

The S&P 500 is down 7.8% in December so far.  This would be the worst month of the year, topping October's 6.9% drop.  Since the S&P 500 started in 1957, December has never been the worst month of the year.  Will Santa save us? Or is 2018 going to break the streak?
S&P 500 before today -   Best 6 days since the Feb '16 lows (+5.99%)  S&P 500 today -  4th 3% drop of the year (-3.24%)
The S&P 500 gained 4.85% last week, the best weekly gain in seven years (Dec '11).  When sentiment gets extremely lopsided, that is what can happen.

The S&P 500 might have bounced off the October lows, but the SPX advance/decline (A/D) line shows many more stocks have improved since then.  This increases the odds that the October lows won't be broken.
This year has been quite volatile.   But would you believe the S&P 500 is in one of the tightest ranges in years?
The S&P 500 went 2 years without a 6-day losing streak.  If lower today, this would be the third 6-day losing streak since October started.
Midterms will get all the headlines this week.  Remember that since WWII, the S&P 500 has been higher 12 months after every single midterm election.
Unless the S&P 500 is green today, it will be the first time in history the entire month of October doesn't have back-to-back green closes.
Unless the S&P 500 closes green today and tomorrow, this will be the first time in history the month of October doesn't have back-to-back gains.
How persistent has the selling been lately?  Today will mark the 28th consecutive day the S&P 500 doesn't have back-to-back up days.   Tying the longest streak since the Great Depression.
Lowest forward P/E multiple for the S&P 500 since early 2016.  Of course, a flat year for stocks and 20% EPS growth will do that.
The Global Dow Index is at the 2007 peak.   This is what you'd call a big level ...

Today could be the 14th day this month the S&P 500 closes red. That is the most for any month since May 2012.  If down today, would be down 14 of 18 trading days so far this month = 78% of all days lower.   This would be the lowest for any month since April 1970 (82%).

Today could be the 75th consecutive day the S&P 500 doesn't close up or down at least 1%.  This is one of the longest streaks in history and sure paints a much different picture than how volatile most think things have been the past few months.

Today could be the first 1% drop for the S&P 500 in 70 trading sessions.  That might feel bad, but remember 4 years ago this month there was a legit fear that ebola was going to spread over the globe.  The SPX is up 55% since those October '14 lows.
Remember - October can be volatile for the S&P 500.  In fact, since 1950, no month has had more 1% changes (up or down) than October.
When the S&P 500 gains >7% in the usually weak Q3 (like it will in '18), what happens in the usually strong Q4?  Since 1950, Q4 has been higher 13 of 14 times with an avg return of +5.9%.
Would you believe the past few months have been among the calmest in the history of the S&P 500?  If all you followed were the headlines, there is no way you'd know this...

Think about all the headlines we've seen the past few months.  Then consider today could be the 80th consecutive day the S&P 500 doesn't close up or down at least 1%. Only last yr and '95 were longer (since '90).  This is one of the most tranquil periods in stock market history.

Since 1954 (and the first Dow new high since the Great Depression), the Dow is a solid indicator of what the economy might do.  After new high, US economy in a recession 6 months later only 0.8% of time. A yr later? Only 2.2%. (13.5% for all instances).
8% of all S&P 500 companies are being moved to a new sector later this month. This is the largest change ever.  Here is how everything will shake out ...

Since 1950, the S&P 500 has been higher in April, May, June, July, and August only 5 times.  2018 will be the 6th time.   The good news? The final 4 months have never been lower and the usually tricky September is actually quite strong.
1987 was the last time the S&P 500 made 4 consecutive highs during the month of August.  It will happen today.

The S&P 500 hasn't closed at a new all-time high for 145 trading days.  Since '50, it has done this only 17 times.  After a new high is finally made? A year later it was higher 16 of those times.  In other words, an eventual new high could be a good sign the bull still has legs.

In honor of the first time the Dow ever fell 1,000 points three years ago today, here is how a 1,000 point drop has looked over history.  There was a time in the early '80s it would have wiped it out.   Today it is 'only' a 3.90% drop.

The S&P 500 is up +1.6% in Aug with a wk to go.  Think about this.  Since 1950, the S&P 500 has been higher each month April - August only 5 times. This year could be the 6th.  The usually weak September is up nicely, but the final 4 months is up every time with an avg of 10.9%.

What is that saying about a dull market?  The S&P 500 has traded in a daily range (from high to low) of only 0.26% yesterday and 0.27% today.  These would be the two smallest intra-day ranges all year!
Stocks usually do well in July, especially the past 10 years.  With the S&P 500 up 4% so far this month, this could be the best July since 2013 ...
We've been saying for months that the S&P 500 will likely make a "Charlie Brown shirt" pattern bottom.  Here is the updated chart. We still expect this to eventually resolve to the upside ...
You really can't make this stuff up...  FridayThe13th tends to be quite strong in summer months for the S&P 500. Can it hold true tomorrow?

Q3 is historically the worse one for stocks.  But what happens when the S&P 500 is higher in April, May, and June (like it was in 2018)?  Wouldn't you know it, Q3 has been higher 9 of the past 10 times (going back to 1980).
90 minutes to go and the S&P 500 just turned green ... can it make it???

One for the bulls Part 2.  What happens when the S&P 500 is higher in both May and June (like 2018 will likely be)?  Since '50, full calendar year has never been lower on a total return basis. That is 22 yrs in a row in the green.  Since '28? 29 of 30 years finished in the green.

One for the bulls.  What happens when the S&P 500 is higher in both May and June (like 2018 will likely be)?  The final six months of the year have been higher the past 11 times in a row.  Going back to 1950? The final 6 months are higher 19 out of 22 times.
So what happens when the S&P 500 closes higher in both May and June (like it could this year)?  The rest of the year has been higher every singe time the past 11 times. Wow.
Remember Sell in May?  2018 could be the third consecutive year that the S&P 500 is higher in both May and June.   Also happened in 2014, so would be 4 of the past 5 years ...

Dow down 8 days in a row will be what you hear today.  Don't forget that since '82, after an 8-day or longer losing streak ends the Dow has been higher 3 months later every single time (six out of six times).
Today will be the 500th day in a row the Dow closes above the 200-day moving average.  That is the longest such streak since (insert scary music here) 1987.

The Dow started trading in 1896.  Should it close red today, this would be the 30th 8-day losing streak ever.  Hasn't hit 9 losses in a row since 1978.  12 is the longest losing streak ever. Happened in 1941 and again in 1968.
There are W bottoms, V bottoms, U bottoms, and many more.  We've been saying for months this one will look more like Charlie Brown's shirt.  Here is the updated S&P 500/Charlie Brown shirt bottom.

So this all happened yesterday.  New all-time highs: Small caps Microcaps Tech Nasdaq NYSE AD line SPX AD line Midcap and small cap AD lines Nasdaq 100 AD line NYSE common stock only AD line S&P 100 AD line  This is strong market breadth and should lead to higher equity prices.
The S&P 500 is up +1.3% in May with a day to go.  Could be the 6th consecutive higher May for the S&P 500.  Sounds like a lot, but no where near the incredible record of 13 in a row from '85 to '97.

Going back the past 25 years, what happens when the S&P 500 is up between 0-5% at the end of May (like this yr will likely be)?  Final 7 months higher 7 of 8 times, with an average return of 8.0%. The avg return the final 7 months of the year is only 4.5% those 25 years.
Would knowing a recession was coming help your investing?  Might not be a simple answer.  Looking at the past 10 recessions, the S&P 500 actually gained during 7 of them.

Let's say earnings growth did peak in Q1. What does it mean?  Well, going back to '50 shows that we could have 49 more months until a recession and a median return of 30% for the S&P 500.   That busts some bearish narratives right there ...

Took the Russell 2000 (small caps) more than 3 months to finally make new all-time highs.  Going back to '13, when it takes small caps that long to make new highs, the S&P 500 has made a new high within 3 months each time (4 for 4).  Small caps tend to lead and could be again.
S&P 500 is 5.2% away from new highs.  Closest it has been since 3/16/18.  That was so long ago I actually thought my  would make the Final Four.

Many are looking for 20% EPS growth in '18 after a great Q1.  Although we think that might be tough to hit, take note that the past 12 times S&P 500 earnings were >10% the S&P 500 Index was higher every single time - up +16.7% on avg.

2018 earnings growth is now expected to be up 18% YoY as of yesterday.  Although this might be a high bar to clear, remember that the past 12 times S&P 500 earnings were up double digits, the full year was higher all 12 times.
2017:  The S&P 500 didn't have a single week that gained or lost 2%.  2018:  Today could be the 6th single DAY over the past 13 days that has moved 2% or more.
67 total trading days so far in 2018 and 27 of those saw the S&P 500 change at least 1%.  Annualized that comes out to 101 1% moves, which would be the most since 2009.
